out.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: from inside an object, container, building, or place
out.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: She opened her suitcase and took out a pair of shoes.
Lock the door on your way out.
Charlotte went to the window and looked out.
Out you go (=used to order someone to leave a room)!
The egg cracked open and out came a baby chick.
The keys must have fallen out of my pocket.
Someone had torn several pages out of her diary.
I don’t think I’d have the courage to jump out of a plane.
All the roads out of the city were snowbound.
out.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: Many of the homeless have been sleeping out for years.
Children were out playing in the snow.
out.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: away from your home, office etc, especially for a short time
out.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Did anyone call while I was out?
My parents are both out at the moment.
out.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to or in a place that is not your home, in order to enjoy yourself
out.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: You should get out and meet people.
Let’s eat out tonight  (=eat in a restaurant).
At first he was too shy to ask her out.
Most teenagers would rather be out and about with their friends.
out.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: in or to a place that is far away or difficult to get to
out.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: He went out to New Zealand.
They’ve rented a farmhouse right out in the country.
out.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: used to say how far away something is
out.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: The Astra Satellite is travelling some 23,000 miles out in space.
a little village about five miles out of Birmingham
out.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: used to say that something is given to many people
out.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The examination will start when all the question papers have been handed out.
Have you sent out the invitations yet?
out.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: used to say that someone gets rid of something or makes it disappear
out.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Have you thrown out yesterday’s paper?
Mother used washing soda to get the stains out.
out.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: a fire or light that is out is no longer burning or shining
out.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: Turn the lights out when you go to bed.
The firefighters arrived, and within minutes the fire was out.
out.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: if the sun, moon, or stars are out, they have appeared in the sky
out.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: When the sun came out, a rainbow formed in the sky.
out.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: if the flowers on a plant are out, they have opened
out.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: It’s still February and already the primroses are out.
out.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: used to say that something is done carefully or completely
out.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: I spent all morning cleaning out the kitchen cupboards.
In the summer months the soil dries out quickly.
out.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: not included in a team, group, competition etc
out.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: The Welsh team was surprisingly knocked out in the semi-finals.
Daniels will be out of the team until he recovers from his injury.
out.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: used to say where something comes from or is taken from
out.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: A lot of good music came out of the hippy culture in the 1960s.
The money is automatically taken out of your bank account every month.
out.translation[0].definitions[14].signp: away from the edge of something
out.translation[0].definitions[14].defin: away from the main part or edge of something
out.translation[0].definitions[14].examp: I swam out into the middle of the lake.
A long peninsula juts out into the sea.
She stuck her head out of the window to see what was happening.
out.translation[0].definitions[15].defin: if a machine, piece of equipment etc is out, it is not working
out.translation[0].definitions[15].examp: I don’t believe it – the elevator’s out again!
out.translation[0].definitions[16].defin: used to say that a product is available to be bought
out.translation[0].definitions[16].examp: Is the new Harry Potter book out yet?
Sony have brought out a new portable music system.
out.translation[0].definitions[17].defin: no longer in a particular state or situation
out.translation[0].definitions[17].examp: She’s not completely cured, but at least she’s out of danger.
This whole situation is getting out of control.
How long have you been out of work now?
Karen waved until the car was out of sight (=too far away to be seen).
out.translation[0].definitions[18].defin: having left the institution where you were
out.translation[0].definitions[18].examp: a kid just out of college
His wife isn’t out of hospital yet.
out.translation[0].definitions[19].examp: Once he was out, he returned to a life of crime.
out.translation[0].definitions[20].examp: You can’t wear that – maxi skirts have been out for years.
out.translation[0].definitions[21].examp: The word’s out that Mel Gibson is in town.
out.translation[0].definitions[22].examp: She fainted – she was out for about ten minutes.
How hard did you hit him? He’s out cold.
out.translation[0].definitions[23].defin: used to say that there is none of something left because you have used it all, sold it all etc
out.translation[0].definitions[23].examp: The album was sold out within minutes.
out.translation[0].definitions[24].defin: if a measurement, result etc is out, it is wrong because the numbers have not been calculated correctly
out.translation[0].definitions[24].examp: He was out in his calculations, so there was a lot of carpet left over.
The bill was out by over £10.
out.translation[0].definitions[25].defin: used to say that someone, especially a political party, no longer has power or authority
out.translation[0].definitions[25].examp: It’s time we voted the Republicans out.
The party has been out of office for a long time.
out.translation[0].definitions[26].defin: used to say that someone has stopped working as a way of protesting about something
out.translation[0].definitions[26].examp: The railway workers have come out in sympathy with the miners.
out.translation[0].definitions[27].defin: if a homosexual is out, they have told people that they are homosexual
out.translation[0].definitions[28].defin: if a particular suggestion or activity is out, it is not possible
out.translation[0].definitions[28].examp: We don’t have enough money to rent a car, so that’s out.
out.translation[0].definitions[29].defin: when the tide is out, the sea by the shore is at its lowest level
out.translation[0].definitions[29].examp: You can walk across the sands when the tide is out.
out.translation[0].definitions[30].defin: a player or team that is out in a game such as cricket  or baseball is no longer allowed to bat
out.translation[0].definitions[31].defin: a ball that is out in a game such as tennis or basketball  is not in the area of play
out.translation[0].definitions[32].defin: because of a particular feeling that you have
out.translation[0].definitions[32].examp: They obeyed him out of fear rather than respect.
Just out of curiosity, why did you take that job?
out.translation[0].definitions[33].defin: used to say what substance or materials a particular thing is made of
out.translation[0].definitions[33].examp: a tombstone carved out of black marble
toy boats made out of old tin cans
out.translation[0].definitions[34].defin: used to say how common something is, or how large a part of a group you are talking about
out.translation[0].definitions[34].examp: Apparently they’ve lost three games out of seven already.
Nine out of ten students pass the test first time.
nine out of ten/three out of four etc
out.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: from the inside to the outside of something – many teachers of British English consider it incorrect to use ‘out’ as a preposition
out.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: Karen looked out the window at the back yard.
Get out the car and push with the rest of us!
out.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to publicly say that someone is homosexual when that person would prefer to keep it secret
out.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: Several politicians have been outed in recent months.
out.translation[2].definitions[0].note_b: Out is usually passive in this meaning
out.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: to let the public know a fact about someone that they would prefer to keep secret
out.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: He was outed as a supporter of the far-right party.
out.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: an excuse to avoid doing an activity or to avoid being blamed for something
out.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: I’m busy on Sunday, so that gives me an out.
out.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: an act of making a player in baseball lose the chance to score a point
out.translation[4].definitions[0].defini: used to form nouns and adjectives from verbs that are followed by ‘out’
out.translation[4].definitions[1].exampl: an outbuilding  (=small building away from the main building)
out.translation[4].definitions[2].defini: being or becoming bigger, further, greater etc than someone or something else
out.translation[4].definitions[2].exampl: He’s outgrown his clothes  (=become too big for them).
She outlived her brother  (=he died before her).
out.translation[4].definitions[3].defini: doing better than someone, so that you defeat them
out.translation[4].definitions[3].exampl: I can out-argue you any day.
out.translation[5].definitions[0].exampl: His new book is due out next spring.
The company plans to bring out a similar product of its own.
out.translation[5].definitions[1].defini: if the workers in a company, factory etc are out, they are refusing to work
out.translation[5].definitions[1].exampl: Teachers in some places stayed out on strike for weeks against the orders of their unions.
out.translation[5].definitions[2].defini: if a worker is out or out sick, they are not at work because they are sick
out.translation[5].definitions[2].exampl: Ralph’s been out sick four times this month already.
out.translation[5].definitions[3].defini: if a machine is out, it is not working
out.translation[5].definitions[4].defini: if your accounts, calculations etc are out, they are wrong
out.translation[5].definitions[4].exampl: The bill was out by over £10.
